transcript.sentence: In this video, content is shared as on screen text. The text is supplemented with icons of people in various arrangements to illustrate the main ideas.
The text is as follows.
Critical thinking
society is growing increasingly contentious and polarized.
The on screen image shows several people on each side of a chasm. And each person says, blah, blah, blah.
Opposing pundits and experts bombard us with facts and opinions.
Who can you believe?
How can you make sense of it? All?
Critical thinking,
skilled active interpretation and evaluation of observations, communications,
Information, and argumentation.
Simply put,
critical thinking is a valuable skill to help us identify arguments.
The screen image is a person using a magnifying glass to examine words on the ground.
And reason about arguments.
The screen image as a person thinking. If a equals b and b equals c then a equals c
in order to come to logical rational conclusions about issues and formulate and present convincing premises to support conclusions.
The screen image identified a tabletop as the conclusion
in the four table legs as premises.
Thereby making reasonable intelligent decisions about what to believe
and to do.
The screen shows a person looking at two potential paths to follow.
When confronted with issues and arguments,
critical thinking provides a checklist to check the logic of the argument or statement.
The on screen images at critical thinking checklist with seven items
clarity,
accuracy
precision
relevance, depth,
breath, and logic.
Clarity.
If a statement is vague or fuzzy,
we can't tell if it's accurate or even relevant.
When we hear vague fuzzy statements we should ask for clarification.
Screen shows an image of a person saying, we must harness our ingenuity and come together to confront and overcome all the challenges we face
to people on the side. Say he's not saying anything. It's just buzz words and fluff.
One person raises her hand and asks,
can you elaborate?
Can you give me an example?
Accuracy
a statement can be clear, but not accurate.
Checking for accuracy.
The screen image shows one person saying chickens are mammals. Another person asks,
is that really true? How can we verify that?
Precision,
a statement can be clear and accurate,
but not precise.
The screen image shows two scales. One scale goes from two light to too heavy,
with the pointer aiming at too heavy.
And the other shows numbers from 180 to 205, with the pointer aiming at 200.
One person says John is overweight.
Another says, can you be more specific or give me more details? Is he 10 pounds overweight or 100 pounds?
The first person says, John is 25 pounds overweight.
Relevance,
a statement can be clear, accurate and precise,
but not relevant to the issue.
The screen image shows a sign that reads. Experienced computer programmers needed apply here.
One person says, I can drive a forklift.
Another person sitting behind a desk says, how is that related to the issue?
Breath,
an argument that only considers one point of view and shuns other perspectives lacks breath.
The screen image shows a newscaster from biased news network saying, blah, blah, blah.
Another person says to be truly fair and unbiased, other points of view must be considered.
Logic
when the combination of thoughts are mutually supporting
and make sense in combination,
the thinking is logical.
If an argument or statement can pass this checklist,
it's probably good thinking.
But if it fails and we still go along with it,
then we aren't being rational, logical human beings.
And if that's the case,
are we really any better than
rats following the pied piper?
Of all life on earth.
Humans have the most advanced brains
capable of rational logical critical thought.
Learn to use your advanced brain, learn to think critically.
Where to learn more
foundation for critical thinking.
W w w dot critical thinking dot org,
and wicker PDA
e n dot wicker PDA dot org
slash wiki slash critical underscore thinking.
Sources
critical thinking, definition,
fisher and scribing
e n dot wicker PDA dot org slash wiki slash critical underscore thinking
and critical thinking standards w w w dot BS u
dot edu slash web
slash l a t r a CE y
slash p b l
slash critical think dot h t m.
Analyze arguments.
The screen image is a person using a microscope to examine the words premise argument issue and conclusion.
Evaluate arguments,
the screen image as a person looking at the words argument, an argument on either side of a fulcrum.
Depth
statements lacked depth when they fail to deal with the complexities of the issue.
The screen image shows a sign reading addressing drug addiction. In America,
a person says, just say no, while another says that superficial,
it doesn't address the physiological and psychological complexities involved in dependency.

result.title: Do You Think?
result.description: With increased societal polarization, especially political, where people are bombarded with "facts" and opinions by pundits and experts, too many people choose to blindly follow their pundit of choice like rats following the Pied Pipers, without really thinking and questioning.  I've felt that if more people were exposed to critical thinking principles, they might at least be able to identify when statements, opinions and actions aren't completely rational. This video is about teaching some very basic critical thinking standards with the intent to intrigue the viewer enough about critical thinking to learn more about the subject.
